title: The ‚ÄòDirty Martini‚Äô Manicure Is The Top Holiday Nail Trend
description: We love a manicure that sounds like a snack. Light blue nail polish is cuter positioned as ‚Äúblueberry milk nails‚Äù and a ‚Äúvanilla manicure‚Äù is more fun than a plain white one ‚Äî it just is. If you‚Äôre ‚Äúdry‚Äù on inspiration for your next manicure, let us introduce the biggest nail trend of the holiday season: the dirty martini manicure. What are dirty martini nails exactly? It‚Äôs not just green polish, but a specific nail art design with a subtle Spanish olive accent that has slowly taken over mood boards, worn by celebrities, like Hailey Bieber, and seen in trendy nail salons from NYC to LA. To dig deeper into the trend ‚Äî and learn exactly how ask for it ‚Äî we went directly to the source, the artist who created the martini olive art months before it became trendy, Betina Goldstein. Rather ironically, Goldstein birthed the ‚Äòdirty martini manicure‚Äô trend back in the fall while she was pregnant. ‚ÄúI created this manicure while I was still pregnant in October and I was looking forward to having a dirty martini,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúI also think dirty martinis are the perfect holiday cocktail.‚Äù How did she craft a dirty martini manicure? Goldstein used gel polish, mixing an olive color, CND Shellac in Olive Grove, into the CND Shellac Base Coat to create the cloudy olive base. She topped the first layer with a CND Shellac Matte Top Coat to get a ‚Äúfrosted glass‚Äù effect and rimmed the tips in a micro French style using CND Shellac in Black Pool, going over it with silver chrome powder to create a glass-like edge. You could stop there. But the olives are the pi√®ce de r√©sistance. Goldstein created 3D olives on her middle and index fingers using a thin brush tool and CND Brisa Glass Hard Sculpting Gel. She painted her olive shapes with a coat of CND Olive Grove (on its own, not diluted with a top coat) and used CND Shellac in Maple Leaves for the pimento accent. Finally, she sealed the olive in place using the CND No Wipe Top Coat. You can also get creative with your base color. For example, Bieber‚Äôs nail artist riffed on this concept using a baby-blue base instead of a translucent-olive one. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Zola Ganzorigt (@nailsbyzola) Another option is using green glitter alongside a glossy olive design, which makes the look a little more festive. Goldstein recommends placing olive accents on the index, middle, finger, or thumb. View this post on Instagram A post shared by AKIKO Nails „Ä∞Ô∏è NYC (@akikonails_nyc) However you slice it, the olive-martini manicure is hot right now. What are dirty martini nails exactly? It's not just green polish, but a specific nail art design with a subtle Spanish olive accent that has slowly taken over mood boards, worn by celebrities, like Hailey Bieber, and seen in trendy nail salons from NYC to LA. To dig deeper into the trend ‚Äî and learn exactly how ask for it ‚Äî we went directly to the source, the artist who created the martini olive art months before it became trendy, Betina Goldstein.

AdvertisementADVERTISEMENT

Rather ironically, Goldstein birthed the 'dirty martini manicure' trend back in the fall while she was pregnant. "I created this manicure while I was still pregnant in October and I was looking forward to having a dirty martini," she explains. "I also think dirty martinis are the perfect holiday cocktail."

Courtesy of Betina Goldstein

You could stop there. But the olives are the pi√®ce de r√©sistance. Goldstein created 3D olives on her middle and index fingers using a thin brush tool and CND Brisa Glass Hard Sculpting Gel. She painted her olive shapes with a coat of CND Olive Grove (on its own, not diluted with a top coat) and used CND Shellac in Maple Leaves for the pimento accent. Finally, she sealed the olive in place using the CND No Wipe Top Coat.

AdvertisementADVERTISEMENT

Of course, if sculptural 3D olives are not in your wheelhouse (or your go-to nail artist's), 2D olives are an easy pivot. You can also get creative with your base color. For example, Bieber's nail artist riffed on this concept using a baby-blue base instead of a translucent-olive one.

Another option is using green glitter alongside a glossy olive design, which makes the look a little more festive. Goldstein recommends placing olive accents on the index, middle, finger, or thumb.

Or, consider a green chrome manicure with a pimento-like accent right in the center of each nail.

However you slice it, the olive-martini manicure is hot right now. It's trendy without being too overtly festive. Plus, it's a good conversation starter at your holiday party. You already know what drink you're ordering.
